texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you try to run Xen without libvirt on Fedora 17 with SELinux in enforcing mode, you'll be butting heads with SELinux in no time. You'll probably be staring at something like this:
texts.text: If you try to run Xen without libvirt on Fedora 17 with SELinux in enforcing mode, you'll be butting heads with SELinux in no time. You'll probably be staring at something like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# xm create -c fedora17
Using config file "/etc/xen/fedora17".
Error: Disk isn't accessible
texts.text:
# xm create -c fedora17
Using config file "/etc/xen/fedora17".
Error: Disk isn't accessible

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: installed, you should have a friendly message in /var/log/messages telling you the source of the problem:
texts.text: installed, you should have a friendly message in /var/log/messages telling you the source of the problem:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from read access on the blk_file dm-1.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l 4d890105-d9a4-4b3e-a674-ba7e952942dc
texts.text:
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from read access on the blk_file dm-1.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l 4d890105-d9a4-4b3e-a674-ba7e952942dc

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The Xen daemon (the python process mentioned in the SELinux denial) is running with a context type of
texts.text: The Xen daemon (the python process mentioned in the SELinux denial) is running with a context type of

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: but the block device I'm trying to use for the VM has
texts.text: but the block device I'm trying to use for the VM has

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# ps axZ | grep xend
system_u:system_r:xend_t:s0       953 ?        SLl    0:40 /usr/bin/python /usr/sbin/xend
# ls -alZ /dev/dm-1
brw-rw----. root disk system_u:object_r:fixed_disk_device_t:s0 /dev/dm-1
texts.text:
# ps axZ | grep xend
system_u:system_r:xend_t:s0       953 ?        SLl    0:40 /usr/bin/python /usr/sbin/xend
# ls -alZ /dev/dm-1
brw-rw----. root disk system_u:object_r:fixed_disk_device_t:s0 /dev/dm-1

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: SELinux isn't going to allow this to work. However, even if we fix this, SELinux will balk about three additional issues and we'll need to adjust the contexts on every new fixed block device we make. To get over the hump, change the context type on your block device to
texts.text: SELinux isn't going to allow this to work. However, even if we fix this, SELinux will balk about three additional issues and we'll need to adjust the contexts on every new fixed block device we make. To get over the hump, change the context type on your block device to

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# chcon -t xen_image_t /dev/dm-1
# ls -alZ /dev/dm-1
brw-rw----. root disk system_u:object_r:xen_image_t:s0 /dev/dm-1
# xm create -c fedora17
Using config file "/etc/xen/fedora17".
Error: out of pty devices
texts.text:
# chcon -t xen_image_t /dev/dm-1
# ls -alZ /dev/dm-1
brw-rw----. root disk system_u:object_r:xen_image_t:s0 /dev/dm-1
# xm create -c fedora17
Using config file "/etc/xen/fedora17".
Error: out of pty devices

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You'll find three new denials in /var/log/messages:
texts.text: You'll find three new denials in /var/log/messages:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from read access on the file group.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l b1392df4-dda4-4b82-914c-1e20c62fc898
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from setattr access on the chr_file 1.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l 3e09edc3-aeb7-49f5-96e1-d8148afda48f
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from execute access on the file pt_chown.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l 86395f09-5f33-4f66-8d02-519b61e54139
texts.text:
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from read access on the file group.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l b1392df4-dda4-4b82-914c-1e20c62fc898
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from setattr access on the chr_file 1.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l 3e09edc3-aeb7-49f5-96e1-d8148afda48f
setroubleshoot: SELinux is preventing /usr/bin/python2.7 from execute access on the file pt_chown.
For complete SELinux messages. run sealert -l 86395f09-5f33-4f66-8d02-519b61e54139

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As much as it pains me to suggest it, you can create a custom module to allow all four of these operations by xend:
texts.text: As much as it pains me to suggest it, you can create a custom module to allow all four of these operations by xend:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
# grep xend /var/log/audit/audit.log | audit2allow -M custom_xen
WARNING: Policy would be downgraded from version 27 to 26.
******************** IMPORTANT ***********************
To make this policy package active, execute:

semodule -i custom_xen.pp

# semodule -i custom_xen.pp
texts.text:
# grep xend /var/log/audit/audit.log | audit2allow -M custom_xen
WARNING: Policy would be downgraded from version 27 to 26.
******************** IMPORTANT ***********************
To make this policy package active, execute:

semodule -i custom_xen.pp

# semodule -i custom_xen.pp

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You should now be able to start your VM without any complaints from SELinux. I'll reiterate that this isn't ideal, but it's the best balance of security and convenience that I've found so far.
texts.text: You should now be able to start your VM without any complaints from SELinux. I'll reiterate that this isn't ideal, but it's the best balance of security and convenience that I've found so far.
